Mr. Horace B. Powell, Page 2, Kerch 12, 1959
There are a few additional facts in which you might be interested. The NASB
Radio Network now distributes nine hours of regular programming a week to 79
NASB member stations, and, in addition, distributes several series of in¬
school programs .each year to those stations broadcasting such programs. The
per hour cost ©^Network programming to member stations is very small. Sta¬
tions pay a Newark fee based on their transmitter power, ranging from $300
to $800 annually. This means that, for stations taking all of the regular
programs offered by the Network, the cost per hour of programming ranges from
6?^ to $1.75. There are other statistics about the total number of programs
distributed since 1951, total air time in hours, etc., which you are probably
not interested in. However, if you do feel this information would be helpful,
please let me know and 1*11 send you the tables and charts.
Since last spring the NAEB has held 3 Regional meetings, supported in part
by Foundation funds. This brings the total of such meetings held since 1951
to 19.
We are "re-gathering” the materials we assembled for you last spring and
should be able to send them to you within a few days. However, I believe
you still have the pictures we sent you from station KETC, St. Louis, and
from the Chicago Board of Education. At least our records so indicate. If
you don* t have them perhaps they became lost in the mail. If a perusal of
the annual report I'm enclosing raises any questions in your mind, or gives
you leads for more information for the report, please let me know and I'll
be glad to supply whatever additional information you want.
Sincerely,
Harold E. Hill
Associate Director
